div.sent: Thera and Theri mean old man and old woman respectively.
But in Buddhist literature Thera is called the monks that are old in wisdom.
They may not be Thera or Theri those who only have observed the life of monks or nuns for several years.
To be a Thera or a Theri mere age is not the factor which may be considered.
On the other hand one can not be Thera or Theri being of the world.
He or she needs to be a monk or nun leaving worldly life.
Then he or she has to quench his or her thirst by worshipping.
There are mentioned a number of Thera-Theri's name in Buddhist literature.
Now we shall know a few biographies of Thera, Theries and some Buddhist personalities.
You will also know some of householder Buddhists that took their place in history by dint of hard perseverance.
Everybody can be Thera-Theri and distinguished Buddhist by dint of acquiring virtue and worshipping eternally.
One can be virtuous and wise scholar like them.
But it needs perseverance.
This was told by the Buddha.
The sentence that uttered by the Buddha never goes in vain.
Mahakassapa was the first Mahasavaka of the Buddha.
By dint of virtuous deeds of his many previous births, once he took birth in Brahmaloka.
Later he took birth at the village Mahatirtha Brahmin under Magadha kingdom at the period of the Buddha.
The name of his father was Kapil Brahmin.
Pipphali Manava was his family name.
Gradually Pipphali Manava grew older and got married.
The name of his wife was Vadra Kapilani.
She was born in the race of Kosiya Brahmin at Sagal Nagar in the kingdom of Madra.
She was paragon of beauty.
Both of them were married by dint of confinement of former existence.
But they were indifferent to worldly life.
Those who take birth from Brahmaloka they do not have attraction to the worldly enjoyment.
So were Pipphali Manava and Vadra Kapilani.
Though they lived a family life, they lived a Brahmacarya life.
After the death of his father, Pipphali Manava got a vast wealth by inheritance.
But he was not satisfied with the riches.
He determined to leave home.
But his wife prevented.
Hearing that her husband will leave home she too wanted to leave home.
The husband said, We should not leave home together.
People will think, none of the husband and wife agreed to leave each other.
This idea will be a crime for them and we shall also commit a sin.
Kapilani then said, You are true.
We shall not take the same way, you are a male.
So you start to go by the right way.
I am a female.
I should go by the left side.
So saying she made obeisance to her husband by going round him three times.
Then she took the left way, Pipphali Manava took the right way.
Just that moment happened an earthquake and there was a terrible sound in the sky.
Gautama Buddha was then at Gandhakutir of Venuvana.
He felt a sudden earthquake and heard a terrible sound.
Then he could realize that the reason of the earthquake was for separation between husband and wife and for their accomplishment.
He also knew that both of them left home for the Buddha.
Then Buddha came out of the hut saying nothing to anybody.
By walking he came far away and sat lotus-like seat under a banyan tree between Rajagriha and Nalanda.
Then the surrounding area became enlightened by his heavenly light.
Pipphali Manava appeared there.
Finding Buddha from distance his mind overflowed with regard.
He appeared before the Buddha and adoring him said, Bhante, Bhagwan, you are my teacher, I am your disciple.
Buddha then praised the qualities of Pipphali Manava.
Then he ordained him as a Bhikkhu by uttering Tisarana.
After becoming monk he was named Mahakassapa.
Buddha proceeded to Venuvana with Mahakassapa.
After poceeding some way Buddha wanted to take rest under a tree.
In a hurry Mahakassapa spread his own robe folding four times and requested Buddha to sit on.
Buddha said, Kassapa, your robe is very soft.
Kassapa thought, as the master told the robe was soft so he would not object to put on it.
So Kassapa requested, Bhante, Bhagwan, you put on this robe.
The master said, Then what will you wear?
Kassapa said, Lord, I will cover my body if I have your worn cloth.
Then they exchanged their robes.
Buddha put on the robe of Kassapa and Kassapa put on the robe of the Buddha.
After that Mahakassapa attained Arahatta within eight days only.
Buddha praised to the monks about the infinite power of Mahakassapa.
The monks placed Mahakassapa to the post of Agramahasavaka finding his infinite power.
On the other hand, Vadra Kapilani received initiation from Mahapajapati Gotami.
After the Mahaparinibbana of Gautama Buddha, Mahakassapa Thera was elected the president unanimously at the first Conference.
The Bhikkhu Sangha present in the meeting entrusted Mahakassapa to select the qualified monks for the Conference.
Not only that he was also entrusted to nominate Bhikkhus who were capable to interrogate matters relating to the Vinaya and (Sutta) Pitakas.
Mahakassapa was one of the best disciples of the Buddha.
He was the wisest, scholar and virtuous monk.
After having Mahaparinibbana of the Buddha the Malla kings tried their best to fire the cremation place, but all of their efforts were in vain.
During the period of the Buddha, the prince of Licchavi was Mahalikumar.
He married the paragan of beauty princess Supravasa of the king Koliya.
Both Mahali Kumar and Supravasa were very pious.
The greatest fortune maker Sivali was born to this pious parents house.
After Supravasa had conceived, the economic condition of the family developed more than before.
Even if Supravasa touched the seeds for sowing the production were increased manifold.
But by dint of the sin committed by in the past life by Supravasa, she had to bear pains of child-birth for seven years.
Not only that but also she had to feel severe pain at the time of delivery for seven days too.
Even she thought that she would not live more.
So she said to her husband, I want to bestow before my death.
You please tell about my desire to the Buddha.
Mahalikumar, her husband told everything to the Buddha.
Buddha then foreseen that a virtuous great man was coming to enlighten the house of Supravasa.
He then blessed, let Supravasa give a safe birth and wished her to be happy.
Supravasa gave birth a beautiful son before Mahalikumar came back home by being blessed by the Buddha.
Then Supravasa made a great gift for seven days.
As the virtuous child took his birth making cool all hearts he was named Sivali.
At early age Sivalikumar entered into the order of the Sanbha under Sariputta Thera.
At the time of cutting hair before giving the robes, Sariputta told him to remember about his sufferings for seven years in the mother's womb.
Sivali listened to the advice of the Thera with great attention and soon attained the Arahatta.
In the past life Sivali went to listen to the religious speech to the Padumuttar Buddha.
At that time Padumuttar Buddha was giving the title Labhi Settho to one of his disciples.
Then he prayed to the Buddha with folding the hands, Bhante, I pray the post Labhi Settho.
Buddha said, You will attain the Labhi Settho during the time of Gautama Buddha.
From that time after many births he obtained the post prayed for and was renowned as Buddha.
The word Labhi Settho means one who is the best of all attainers, i.e. he will gain whatever he likes.
At the previous lives Sivali did many good deeds, so he could gain wherever he liked to gain anything at the Sivali-birth.
The Buddhists still believe that none would be needy if he worships Sivali and recites the Sivali Parittana Sutta.
After attaining the Arahatta Sivali Thera recited the following verse (Gatha) : I have destroyed dignity and pride after searching wisdom and immunity.
I have reached the destination for which I entered the hut.
Many of the disciples of the Buddha attained the power of prosperity (Riddhi).
Riddhi means to show supernatural power by dint of religious obstruction.
Those who gain this power can make impossible to possible.
This power of prosperity attained many of the disciples of the Buddha, too.
Theri Utpalabanna was the best of them.
But she did not gain this power of prosperity in one life.
She had to meditate many past lives.
She had to attain virtues for many births.
Now we shall tell about the previous life of the great virtuous lady Utpalabanna.
During the period of Padurnuttar Buddha Utpalabanna took birth in a respectable family of Hangsabati Nagar.
From her childhood she was virtuous.
She often used to go to the monastery.
After she had gone to the monastery, she saw that Padumuttar Buddha offered a nun the place of best Riddhimati.
Finding this Utpalabanna desired herself to be the best Riddhimati.
Then Utpalabanna worshipped highly to Padumuttar Buddha and his disciples for a week.
She conveyed her best regard to Buddha and then prayed to him for the best Riddhimati.
Padumuttar Buddha blessed Utpalabanna.
After that Utpalabanna attained virtues for many births and at last she was born in Sravasti during the period of Gautama Buddha.
Her father's name was Tatratya Setthi.
Setthi means a great rich man.
He named his daughter Utpalabanna.
Utpal means blue lotus.
As her colour was like blue lotus she was named Utpalabanna.
Not only in beauty but also in virtue she was second to none.
Gradually Utpalabanna was grown up.
It was spread out all over about her virtue, and beauty.
Attracting by her virtue and beauty many kings, maharajas and rich men from different provinces sent proposals to marry her.
The Setthi fell in a great danger.
If he made marry her daughter with a king, another king would be dissatisfied.
The number of enemies would increase.
Beyond this, there might be quarrel among the candidates before the marriage ceremony.
So, for escaping from this danger he felt to find out an alternative ways.
Then he said to his daughter, Can you be a nun?
By dint of virtue of her previous life, she became very glad to hear the word nun and said, Yes father, I am ready.
The Setthi became glad and he took Utpalabanna with him to the nuns.
The nuns accepted her in the order of the Nuns.
After this Utpalabanna, was offered the responsibility of the house of the worshippers.
Later, by dint of meditation she attained heavenly (spiritual) vision and supernatural knowledge.
Then she attained Arahatta and the power of prosperity.
Later, the Buddha offered Utpalabanna the seat of the best of all in the power of prosperity in the Conference of Sangha at Jetavana.
Utpalabanna recited some verses after having a thought of great happiness-and fulfillment of meditation.
The memory of the past life is in my possession.
I have attained the knowledge to read the mind of others.
I have got the spiritual vision and supernatural knowledge.
I have attained power of prosperity.
I am free from addiction.
I am at home in six fold experience.
I have fulfilled the desire of the Great Buddha.
When Mara (enemy) came to disturb Utpalabanna at Shasakakunja, she told, You would not be able to harm me in the least.
What will you do alone?
At once I can enter in your body invisibly.
I am standing between your pair of eyebrows.
But you have no power to feel my existence?
Patachara was born in a respectable family in Hangsabati Nagar during the period of Padumuttar Buddha.
She was devoted to religion from her early life.
One day she went to the monastery to listen to the preaching of the Buddha while she was grown up.
At the time of listening religious speech she saw, Buddha conferred the title Vinaydhar on a nun.
Among the nuns those who were experienced in the rules of the Sangha they would be conveyed this place.
Seeing a respectable place offered to a nun, Patachara desired to gain this place, too.
Hoping to obtain this rare position Patachara engaged herself in virtuous deeds throughout her life.
After that Patachara took birth in the world for several times.
Every time she gathered virtues with her virtuous works.
Thus she lived holy life for twenty thousand years.
In one of her past lives she built a monastery and offered to the Bhikkhu Sangha for their dwelling.
By dint of infinite virtues she took birth in the race of gods.
During the period of Gautama Buddha, Patachara was born in the royal Treasurer's house of Sravasti Nagar.
She became grown up day by day.
She became adorned with matchless beauty.
Thus Patachara became marriageable.
But she married a poor- young man of her choice against the will of her father.
Then she left her father's house and lived in another village with her husband.
Patachara became pregnant.
Then she felt repentant.
She could realize her own fault.
One day she told her husband, Let us go to my fathers house.
The husband delayed saying, Well go today, tomorrow.
Patachara realized that her husband will not take her to her father's house.
So one day in the absence of her husband she started for father's house.
At the time of leaving she told neighbours, 'I am going to my father's house.
Please tell this to my husband when he comes back.
Coming back home the husband saw that her wife was not in the house.
Getting the news from the neighbours he was repentant.
He thought, the helpless condition of the rich-daughter Patachara was only for him.
Then the husband hurriedly followed her.
On the half way the husband met his wife.
By this time .
Patachara gave birth to a male child on the way.
Patachara again went back their home with her husband and the child.
Patachara again became pregnant.
This time she started for her father's house with her husband.
On the way at the dead of night Patachara felt pain of childbirth.
Then heavy storm began to flow.
The lightning was startled every now and then.
It started terrible thundering.
Later it started hail-storm vehemently.
Patachara was a daughter of a rich man.
She never fell on such a trouble.
Patachara told her husband to take her to a place where there is no storm or rainfall.
On the stormy night Patachara gave birth to another son.
She passed whole night waiting for her husband with the children.
In the morning she found her husband dead and bewailed for loss.
Finding no other way Patachara started for her father's house with her two kids.
There was a river in front.
The river-water increased due to heavy rainfall in the whole night.
Patachara sensed a danger.
But she had to go.
Standing on the bank of the river she thought, it was impossible to across the river with her two babies at a time.
So she left the elder son on this bank and accrossed the river with the new born.
On the opposite bank of the river she kept the little child wrapping on a piece of cloth and again started for the other bank.
When she had reached the middle of the river she found a hawk flying in the sky with her suckling-child.
Patachara clapped many times to threat the hawk .
But it was fruitless.
The hawk went far away with the baby.
The elder child, hearing the voice of his mother thought that she was calling him.
Then he jumped to the river and drowned at the moment.
Losing both the child Patachara reached Sravasti weeping.
Arriving here she came to know that her parents and brothers also died in the previous night.
Patachara could not bear grief and she then walked about the way overwhelmed with grief.
She could not realize that her worn clothes had been opened from her body.
She became mad and arrived in front of the Jetavana garden.
By this time Gautama Buddha was initiating his devotees.
Some people were throwing stones at Patachara.
Gautama Buddha told the people to bring her before him.
Patachara was taken to him.
Then the Buddha said, Sister, let your memories come back.
Being blessed by the Buddha Patachara recovered her senses.
Then she saw that she had no clothes in her body.
Being ashamed she sat down hurriedly on the ground.
Then someone helped her with a cloth.
Patachara then sat down on the foot of the Buddha and said, Bhagwan, please save me.
Patachara told the Buddha everything that happened.
The Buddha consoled and advised her and said, Patachara, it is not possible to get back what you have lost.
You had to cry even in the past life for several times like this life.
You had shed tears more than the water of four oceans.
So don't spoil your life by mourning'.
Patachara became calm listening to the advice of the Buddha.
She attained Sotapatti Phal on listening to the advice of the Buddha.
The Buddha initiated her into Bhikkhuni Sangha.
At last she attained Arahatta by absorbing herself on meditation.
One evening, while I was washing my legs I noticed that water flows downwards.
Finding this I pacified my mind as a well bred horse receives its training.
Then I entered in the monastery with a candle.
Later I sat upon the stage looking at the bed.
I put out the candle.
The trouble of my heart put out as the candle too.
Jivaka's mother's name was Shalavati.
It is said that the mother Shalavati threw Jivaka in the dustbin after he was born.
By this time prince Abhoy, the son of king Bimbisara was passing by this way.
He saw some crows were crowing surrounding something.
He asked the people and knew that the crows were crying surrounding a new-born child.
He asked, Is the baby alive?
The people said, Yes it is alive.
Then he took the baby and gave it to the midwives.
As the child was alive it was named Jivaka.
He was growing up in the palace.
Thus he became sixteen years old.
If there happened any quarrel among the fellows the princes laughed at him calling the orphan.
One day Jivaka asked the prince Abhoy, Deva, who is my mother and who is my father?
The prince Abhoy said, Son!
I don't know who is your mother.
But I brought you up.
So I am your father.
Jivaka understood, his life would not pass by this way.
Though he was growing up in the palace he had no right to it.
He had to stand on his own foot.
One day Jivaka left the palace saying nothing to anybody.
Once he arrived at Taxila.
At that time there lived a well-known physician at Taxila.
Jivaka appeared before and said, Teacher, I want to study medical science under you.
But I have no ability to pay you any money.
I shall be ever grateful to you if you teach me.
Being satisfied at his word the teacher began to teach him.
Jivaka also started learning very attentively.
Seven years passed.
Jivaka attained deep knowledge in medical science.
One day he asked the teacher, Sir, have I finished my lessons?
After four days Jivaka told the teacher, Sir, I have not found any leaf or plant that will not need as medicine.
The teacher was very glad at Jivakas reply and said, You have completed your lesson.
This is enough for your livelihood.
So saying the teacher permitted Jivaka to go back his home.
He gave Jivaka traveling expenses too.
On the way to Magadha, after arriving at Saketa Nagar, all his money was expended.
Jivaka thought, I need traveling expenses.
After enquiry he was informed that the wife of a Setthi of Saket had been suffering from head-ache for seven years.
Many physicians tried but none could cure her disease.
Jivaka went to the house of that richman.
The wife of Setthi came round after Jivaka's treatment.
The richman gave Jivaka sufficient money and servants.
He also gave him horses to carry those wealth.
Then Jivaka came back to Magadha to stay with Abhoy.
At that time king Bimbisara was attacked by fistula disease.
King Bimbisara came round very soon after having treatment from Jivaka.
The king became happy and gave him plenty of money.
The king appointed Jivaka as royal physician.
He also cured many rich men of Rajagriha.
He cured king Pradyut of Ujjayani from a complicated disease.
Gradually his fame spread out all around as a famous physician.
Jivaka was initiated himself into the Buddhism after twenty years of Tathagata's attaining the supreme Enlightenment.
Once the Buddha became ill.
He came round at the treatment of Jivaka.
From that time Jivaka was the permanent physician of the Buddha.
Not only that he treated the Bhikkhu Sangha too.
Once there broke out leprosy and leucoderma in Magadha.
The patients began to come to Jivaka in groups.
In fact, Jivaka was the house-physician of king Bimbisara and the permanent physician of the Buddha and the Bhikkhu Sangha.
He had no time to attend others.
So he sent them back without treatment.
Then they thought, Jivaka would be compelled to treat them if they became the monks.
So they started to become monks after they had initiated into the order of the Sangha.
But after they had come round by the treatment of Jivaka they gave up Bhikkhu-dhamma.
Then Jivaka informed the matter to the Buddha.
The Buddha then called the other Bhikkhus.
You will not initiate the dangerous patients who are attacked by the leprosy, leucoderma and tuberculosis diseases.
From that time the patients attacked by the disease like leprosy, leucoderma and tuberculosis were prohibitted to enter into the order of the Sangha.
Jivaka was the best physician of the ancient India.
He was renowned as the name Viskacharya.
Archaeological excavation in Rajgir unearthed the mango orchard and the houses of Jivaka.
Buddhaghosh has a mentionable contributions in the Buddhists literature.
Details of his life is not known.
It is known through various sources that he lived the fifth century A.D. Perhaps he was born in a certain village near Buddha Gaya.
His father was Brahmin scholar.
So he also learnt Triveda in his early age.
He was defeated in debate by a scholar monk.
He was charmed hearing Abhidhamma from the scholar monk and then he embraced Buddhism.
It is said that his voice was as distinct and deep as the Buddha, for which he was renowned as the name Buddhaghosh.
Buddhaghosh was very meritorious.
After initiating Buddhism he studied Tripitaka and became scholar within short period.
By this time he composed a book named Jnanodaya.
He composed a speakable writing named Atthasalini upon Dhammasangani.
Finding wisdom and skill in Buddhaghosh Bhikkhu Sangha gave him a responsibility to translate the whole Atthakatha in Pali language after having gone to Ceylon.
Buddhaghosh went to Ceylon with the permission of the Bhikkhu Sangha.
There he studied Tripitaka and Atthakatha at the Mahavihara of Anuradhapur.
Buddhaghosh requested the monks of Ceylon to translate the Atthakatha composed in Sinhali language into Pali language.
The Bhikkhu Sangha of Ceylon permitted him to translate Atthakatha finding his skill in writing.
For this he was also permitted to enter into the library of Mahavihara in Anuradhapur.
After hard labour Buddhaghosh translated the whole Atthakatha in Pali language.
Then he returned to his own country.
Thus the great scholar Buddhaghosh made a great conribution to the Buddhist literature.
He wrote the hard subjects of Tripitaka in easy language as it could be comprehensible to all.
His Atthakatha is still well-known as an annotation and explanatory book.
Buddhaghosh will be immortal only for this book-though he has written many other books.
